about-body.value:
Originally from Washington state, I currently live in Lakewood just outside the JBLM military base with my pup Huey P. In addition to taking long walks with my dog, I also enjoy listening to 80’s love ballads on repeat, practicing and teaching hot yoga, cooking with friends, taking art classes and making artist books, dabbling in astrology and tarot, and roller skating. I value building community, mentorship, and softness as a radical form of activism. 

I am a Ph.D. Candidate in the Department of Communication at the University of Washington. I received my B.A. in English, with a Creative Writing minor from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill in 2013, and an M.A. in Cultural Studies from the University of Washington, Bothell in 2017. My research looks at representations of difference and identity in the media using Black feminist critical-cultural communication theories and methods. As an interdisciplinary scholar, my work draws on the fields of Black Studies and Critical Mixed Race Studies, Gender and Sexuality Studies, American Studies, and Comic Studies. I am concurrently working on three graduate certificates at the University of Washington in: Science, Technology, and Society Studies; Gender and Sexuality Studies; and Public Scholarship.

In addition to presenting my research at scholarly conferences, such as the Society for Cinema and Media Studies (SCMS) and the American Studies Association (ASA), I have a forthcoming co-authored article in the Journal for Women’s Studies in Communication entitled “‘You’re the Whitest Black Person I Know’: Interrupting Microaggressions Through a Poetics of Interruption.” I also have two lead-authored book chapters in edited volumes, Studying Race and Media (NYU Press, 2020) and Confronting Equity and Inclusion Incidents on Campus (Routledge, 2021) and several smaller pieces in Somatechnics, Lateral, and Souls. My critical arts writing practice has led to publications in Art Practical, A Year in Black Art, and New Archives.

Beyond serving as a graduate staff assistant and research assistant in the past I have taught several asynchronous and synchronous courses on topics such as Black Cultural Studies and Race, Gender, and Sexuality in the Media. Currently, I am the Vice President of Equity and Accountability for the Graduate and Professional Student Senate (GPSS) where I represent over 15,000 students on campus. 

My work has been recognized by the Association of American Colleges and Universities wherein I received a 2021 K. Patricia Cross Future Leaders Award. I continue to receive institutional support for my studies from the Graduate Opportunities for Minority Achievement and Programs (GO-MAP), the Center for Communication, Difference, and Equity (CCDE), and the Walter Chapin Simpson Center for the Humanities. I have held a resident fellowship in the Black Embodiment Studio for the last several years. I enjoy giving talks and have presented as the keynote speaker for the 2020 UW Diversity Leadership Conference and at Gonzaga University’s COMMVersations on Activism and Civic Engagement. 

I host a daily writing group for the Communication and Difference Research Group (CDRG). Dr. Ralina Joseph is the chair of my committee and other committee members include Drs. LeiLani Nishime, Kemi Adeyemi, and Sasha Su-Ling Welland. I am an active sister of Theta Nu Xi Multicultural Sorority, Inc. and a co-founder of the Mixed Comix Collective, as well as the UW Bothell Graduate student club, G-LEAD. You can find more information about my research, awards, and professional experience by visiting my C.V.

Is grad school right for me? by Aleenah Ansari for UW’s The Daily (2019)

research-body.value:
Dissertation

The Political Aesthetics of Black Girl Magic: Self-Representation in Alternative Media

Abstract:

In this project, I answer the question: What is Black Girl Magic (BGM) and how does it help us rethink the human? Most simply put, Black Girl Magic entails three key components of metaphorical witchcraft: Flight (movement), Brew (materiality), and Brood (libidinality). BGM is not just the combination of these various aspects, rather, it is a dynamic animation of their inter-imbricated mechanics. Such animation moves these mechanics from a way of knowing, into a way of being.  

This dissertation surveys representations of queer Black women in alternative media such as comix, artist books, and in the digital realm.  Tracing the AfroFemme-inist politics of “Black Girl Magic,” it unpacks self-representation as a way of speaking back to power. As a critical-cultural communication and media studies research project, it contributes to growing bodies of literature on Black, mixed-race, and queer subjectivities. Observed through the aesthetics of niche cultural productions like underground comics and cosplay, digital media and blogs, artist books, and independent art collectives and salons, the most minute expressions afford an archive of speech acts that signify quotidian forms of Black feminist poetics. Termed “the witch’s brew,” such aesthetics depict the political struggle and transformative potential of communicating across differences in resistance to systems of oppression. 

The first part of the project offers textual and rhetorical analysis of the comic Bitch Planet (2015) and a DIY-performance of the mixed-race character Penny Rolle, as well as an auteur study of the young actress Amandla Stenberg and her repertoire of Hollywood films and independent YouTube videos. In each case study, mainstream media reflects a dominant ideology of the “split self” that the alternative media cogently resists. Part two takes shape as public scholarship, including the curation of an online exhibit of artist books and other oddities, as well as the creation of my own artist book, Which Witch.

Wielding archival sciences as tools towards refashioning conceptions of what it means to be human, this portion of the project theorizes the relationship between form and materiality as it relates to the intersectional standpoint of queer Black femme subjectivities. Part three engages community-based art salons and (auto)ethnographic methods to show rather than tell how artists of color, like those at the Independent Publishing Resource Center in Portland, challenge conventions of the press by taking it into their own hands as a form of collective self-determination and alternative world-building. While each section methodologically stands apart, together they culminate into a praxis-based documentation of how queer Black women make themselves using Black Girl Magic.

sink-content-1.value:
Keep close to Nature's heart...

and break clear away, once in awhile, and climb a mountain or spend a week in the woods.

Wash your spirit clean.

teaching-body.value:
At the University of Washington, I teach upper-level undergraduate courses that are cross-listed in multiple departments including Gender, Women, and Sexuality Studies (GWSS), Communication (COM), and American Ethnic Studies (AES). I have also taught community college courses through the Freedom Education Project of Puget Sound at the Gig Harbor Women’s Correctional Facility, and have taught high school students through the Upward Bound program put on by the Office of Minority Affairs and Diversity at UW.

[Images (2)]

My pedagogical philosophy is structured by an ethos of public scholarship. The instructor, like a researcher, works with a select group of participants as co-researchers. In this case, the students within the context of a classroom participate in what functions much like workshop-based focus groups where knowledge is shared laterally, meaning is co-produced, labor is reciprocated, and power is held accountable. With me, students follow academic paths that allow them to assess the world “out there” using resources from within the ivory tower. Unearthing their personal experiences as pertinent to their perceptions and knowledge production, I advocate alongside them for their imagined and proposed solutions to be taken as intrinsically key in solving our most pertinent problems.

My courses present students with large-scale social problems of difference and identity in the media with the goal of collectively determining how to best solve the real-world obstacles they face. The classroom is a crucible or live learning-lab for us to all practice, play with, and pursue various understandings of communication, power, and difference. Each student possesses a particular perspective that is advantageous to the rest of the class’s learning experience. By harnessing the unique details of their journeys, I seek to cultivate civic leaders who know how to critically and collectively think about the larger problems in our world while understanding the intersectionality of those issues in particular publics, and how to overcome obstacles of power and difference in how they go about informing and sharing what they’ve learned. 

Previously Taught Courses:            

COM/AES/GWSS 389: Race, Gender, and Sexuality in the Media                                                                                                                                          

COM/AES/GWSS 489: Black Cultural Studies                                               

COM/AES/GWSS 490: Representing Beyond the Binaries: Race, Gender, Sexuality in the Media                       

CMST 110: Intercultural/Multicultural Communication                                                        

CMST 220: Public Speaking

Prepared Courses:

Screen Studies (Undergraduate)

Communicating Identity & Difference in Comics (Undergraduate/Graduate)

Study Abroad: Travel and Cultural Difference (Undergraduate/ Graduate)

Prospective Courses:

Community Engaged Scholarship: Methods for Visualizing Gentrification (Undergraduate) Public Speaking: Talking About Difference (Undergraduate)

Communication, Power, and Difference (Undergraduate)

Reading & Making Black Artist Books (Graduate)

…. and many more!

writing-body.value:
In Progress

“A Lab Report from the Communication and Difference Research Group: Zooming Through Virtual Hallways Together” by Meshell Sturgis, Anjuli Joshi Brekke, Jas L. Moultrie, Laura Irwin, Autumn Diaz, Seonah Kim, and Andrea Otáñez in Communication, Culture, and Critique. Under Review.  

Articles

“’You’re the Whitest Black Person I Know’: Speaking Back to Microaggressions with a Poetics of Interruption” by Meshell Sturgis and Ralina L. Joseph in the Journal of Women’s Studies in Communication. Accepted. 

“Getting Home: With Language, Love, and Practice” by Meshell Sturgis in a special issue of QED: A Journal in GLBTQ Worldmaking edited by Shinsuke Eguchi, 8 (2), 2021. In Press.

Book Chapters

“Visualizing Mixed Race” by Meshell Sturgis and Ralina L. Joseph in Studying Race and 

Media edited by Lori Lopez with NYU Press, 2020.

“Who is Listening to What We Have to Say?: Talking About Institutional Diversity at the University of Washington” by Meshell Sturgis, Brian Evans, Anjuli Brekke, Erin Lee, and Andrea Delgado in Confronting Critical Equity and Inclusion Incidents on Campus: Lessons Learned and Emerging Practices edited by Hannah Oliha-Donaldson with Routledge, 2021. 

Reviews

“Review of Fearing the Black Body: The Racial Origins of Fat Phobia by Sabrina Strings (New York University Press)” by Meshell Sturgis in Lateral: Journal of the Cultural Studies Association. 

“Review: The Rachel Divide” by Meshell Sturgis and Victoria Thomas in the Journal of Women’s Studies in Communication, 4(3). 2020.

“Roundtable Review: The Right to Maim: Somatechnologies of Violence, Race, and Disability” with Gilbert Caluya, Gerard Goggin, Zsuzsanna Dominika Ihar, Jack Leff, Kelly Sharron, and Meshell Sturgis in Somatechnics 9 no. 2-3, pp. 376-400, edited by Holly Randell-Moon, 2019. 

Art Reviews 

“We’re on the Same Page: In Conversation with Danny Giles” by Meshell Sturgis in A Year in Black Art 2018-2019, vol. 2, pp. 16-21, 2019. 

“Becoming Undone: Ko Kirk Yamahira at the Frye Art Museum” by Meshell Sturgis for Art Practical, 2018. 

“Waiting to Exhale: Comic and Iconic Figures by MoNoise.” in A Year in Black Art 2017-2018, vol. 1, 2018. 

“MoNoise at Essentia – A Memory Foam Mattress Store” by Meshell Sturgis for Art Practical, 2018.
